text:
(1)
Park Ave., east side, north from East 39th to 40th Streets. Shown at the N.E. corner is a country home, erected for demonstration purposes. Buildings standing at the S.E. corner of 40th Street, are Nos. 93-99 inclusive. No. 99-97 (at and adjoining the corner), is the Nurses Club;
March 22, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A closer view of "America's Little House".
March 22, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

This entire block front has been purchased by the City as a new site of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court. On completion of same they will move from their present quarters at the N.E. corner of Madison Ave. and East 25th Street. The Henry Street Visiting Nurse Service have purchased the former Wm. Goadby Loew residence at the S.W. corner of Madison Ave. and East 39th Street and will shortly move their executive offices there after remodeling to meet their needs. For a fuller account see the New York Sun of February 15, 1936 and March 29, 1938 and the New York Times of March 25, 1938.

115, 117, 119 East 39th Street, north side, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

March, 1913.

Brown Brothers.
33 East 39th Street, north side, between Park and Madison Avenues, at the time of its purchase by a family returning to Murray Hill. 1916.

30, 28, 26 East 39th Street, south side, between Park and Madison Avenues. No. 28 is the Psi Upsilon Club of New York. About 1920.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

117, 119, 121 East 39th Street, north side, between park and Lexington Avenues.
1921.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

{(1)k
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from 40th Street across the lot left by demolition of buildings on the S.W. corner of 40th Street. The house shown on the S.E. corner of 40th Street is the Visiting Nurses' Club, and the adjoining house the Navy Club. The rest of the buildings in the block will be demolished in 1933.
December 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same, but seen across the Avenue from 39th Street, and showing demolition of the old brownstone houses, leaving only the two in the northern end of the block.
September 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

{(1)k
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from 40th Street across the lot left by demolition of buildings on the S.W. corner of 40th Street. The house shown on the S.E. corner of 40th Street is the Visiting Nurses' Club, and the adjoining house the Navy Club. The rest of the buildings in the block will be demolished in 1933.
December 3, 1931.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The same, but seen across the Avenue from 39th Street, and showing demolition of the old brownstone houses, leaving only the two in the northern end of the block.
September 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

77 Park Avenue at the S.E. corner of 39th Street, a new apartment house nearing completion. This entire block has been rebuilt since 1921; the building partly shown on the right is the corner house at 38th Street which replaced the old C. D. Barney house in 1922. Compare this picture with the N.E. corner of 38th Street in early 1922 and notice also how the center parks have been modernized to leave more room for motor traffic.

1924.

Joseph Smith.

(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from the tall building at 271 Madison Avenue, showing the Nurses Club at the N.E. corner of 40th Street and the Navy Club adjoining it. The other houses in the block, beginning with the small one in the middle, are to be demolished in 1933. In the background may be seen some of the 42nd Street skyscraper the twin buildings of Tudor City overlooking the East River, the dim outlines of Long Island City on the other side.
December 2, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same, at an earlier date.
October 12, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
N-~ 292G

Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 40th Streets, seen from the tall building at 271 Madison Avenue, showing the Nurses Club at the N.E. corner of 40th Street and the Navy Club adjoining it. N-~ 292G

(1)
Park Avenue at S.W. corner of 39th Street, showing old mansion and two houses adjacent on Park Avenue which will be demolished in 1933. The top of the Allerton House Fraternity Clubs building at Madison Avenue and 38th Street is just visible over the roof of the corner house.
May 31, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, five years later, showing demolition nearly complete. The large blank wall shown in the center of the picture is that of the first house on the south side of 39th Street. In the background rise the towers of the Allerton House Fraternity Clubs, on the S.E. corner of 38th Street, the International Combustion Building at 200 Madison Avenue, and, between them, the Empire State Building.
September 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, after completion of the demolition.
October 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Park Avenue at S.W. corner of 39th Street, showing old mansion and two houses adjacent on Park Avenue which will be demolished in 1933. The top of the Allerton House Fraternity Clubs building at Madison Avenue and 38th Street is just visible over the roof of the corner house.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

(3)
The same, after completion of the demolition.
October 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue, south from and including 39th Street, seen from the top of the Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street. Below 32nd Street the eastern side of Fourth Avenue, down to Union Square, is visible. In the left background the New York Edison tower, on 14th Street between Irving Place and Third Avenue, rises out of the haze. To the west of Fourth Avenue, much nearer, are the towers of the New York Life Building (27th to 26th Streets) and the Metropolitan Tower on the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue and 24th Street.

Park Avenue begins at 32nd Street. The new One Park Avenue building is seen to the left, and Two Park Avenue to the right. In the block from 33rd to 34th Streets you can see the entrance to the old tunnel. The 71st Regiment Armory is on the east side, and the Hotel Vanderbilt on the west (in front of Two Park Avenue). The following construction is under way on or near Park Avenue; No. 7 Park Avenue, an L-shaped apartment building surrounding the N.E. corner of 34th Street; the new Union League clubhouse on the S.W. corner of 37th Street; and the Town House apartment building at 108 East 38th Street. In 1933 the small houses on the S.W. and N.E. corners of 39th Street will be demolished. The latter corner will be occupied in 1935 by America's Little House.

1930.

Ewing Galloway.

(1)
90-92 Park Avenue, west side, between 39th and 40th Streets: two old houses which are to be demolished in October 1931.
December 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The adjoining houses Nos. 94, 96 and 98 Park Ave., at, adjoining, and south of the S.W. corner of East 40th Street.

December 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
90-92 Park Avenue, west side, between 39th and 40th Streets: two old houses which are to be demolished in October 1931.
December 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(2)
The adjoining houses Nos. 94, 96 and 98 Park Ave., at, adjoining, and south of the S.W. corner of East 40th Street.

December 13, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

39th Street, north side, west from but not including Park Avenue. December 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue, north on west side, from 39th to 42nd Streets, showing the Princeton Club at the N.W. corner of 39th Street and the three buildings in the northern half of that block which are about to be demolished. The Hotel Belmont, in the block from 41st to 42nd Streets, above the Murray Hill Hotel, has just been demolished. In the background are shown the Lefcourt Colonial Building at Madison Avenue and 41st Street, and the Lincoln Building at 60 East 42nd Street.

August 25, 1931.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

Park Avenue, west side, from 40th to 39th Streets, showing Murray Hill Hotel on the N.W. corner of 40th Street; the view is from the Pershing Square Building on the east side at 41st Street. The old houses which are being demolished on the S.W. corner of 40th Street will be replaced in 1933 by a white two-story structure with stores. The buildings on the S.W. corner of 39th Street will be demolished in September, 1933. The elevation of the camera gives an especially good view of the Empire State Building at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, the tallest building in the world.

October 21, 1931.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 39th Streets, showing the Pershing Square Viaduct and the Pershing Square Building, built about 1923 in the block from 42nd to 41st Streets where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand. In the right foreground, opposite this building, the Hotel Belmont (opened 1906) is in the final stages of demolition.
103 Park Avenue, on the S.E. corner of 41st Street, was built about 1900, and 101 Park Avenue, on the N.E. corner of 40th Street, in 1916.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing less of the Pershing Square Building and more of the demolition of the Belmont on the west side of the Avenue.
The tower in the background, incidentally, is the colored tower of the new Town House apartment building at 106 East 38th Street.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The Pershing Square Building only.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Park Avenue, east side, from 42nd to 39th Streets, showing the Pershing Square Viaduct and the Pershing Square Building, built about 1923 in the block from 42nd to 41st Streets where the Grand Union Hotel used to stand. In the right foreground, opposite this building, the Hotel Belmont (opened 1906) is in the final stages of demolition.
103 Park Avenue, on the S.E. corner of 41st Street, was built about 1900, and 101 Park Avenue, on the N.E. corner of 40th Street, in 1916.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing less of the Pershing Square Building and more of the demolition of the Belmont on the west side of the Avenue.
The tower in the background, incidentally, is the colored tower of the new Town House apartment building at 106 East 38th Street.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The Pershing Square Building only.
August 25, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

39th Street, north side, west from No. 115, east of Park Avenue.
September 9, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

39th Street, north side, from park to Fifth Avenues, showing the tower of 9 East 39th Street or 10 East 40th Street.
October 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue, east side, from 39th to 42nd Streets, showing demolition of houses from the N.E. corner of 39th Street to and including the little one in the middle of the block. On the site thus vacant the Little House will be erected late in 1934. On the N.E. corner of 40th Street stands the Architects' Building (1916), and above it the smaller and older 103 Park Avenue. The Pershing Square Building follows in the block from 41st to 42nd Streets, where the Grand Union Hotel stood prior to 1915.
In the background the Chanin Building partly hides the tower of the Chrysler Building.

September 10, 1933.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

(1)
39th Street, north side, from Park to Madison Avenues, a view of the roofs and of the skyscrapers in the background, and not showing the Park Avenue corner.
December 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a view of the fronts of the houses, four years later, showing the Princeton Club at the corner of Park Avenue but not showing the Madison Avenue corner.
March 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
39th Street, north side, from Park to Madison Avenues, a view of the roofs and of the skyscrapers in the background, and not showing the Park Avenue corner.
December 2, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a view of the fronts of the houses, four years later, showing the Princeton Club at the corner of Park Avenue but not showing the Madison Avenue corner.
March 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Park Avenue at 39th Street, seen from 39th Street west of the Avenue.
On the N.W. corner stands the Princeton Club; and the S.W. corner is shown vacant, buildings having been demolished in September 1933. It will later be used as a parking space.
On the N.E. corner, set back from the street, is the Little House, a model home built on the site, which was cleared in 1933, by the New York Committee of Better Homes in America, and opened for public inspection November 1934. On the same side of 39th Street, east of Lexington Avenue, may be seen one of the Allerton Houses, an apartment hotel for men.
The apartment house on the S.E. corner of Park Avenue and 39th Street was built in 1924.

P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

Park Ave., north from East 39th Street, showing W.P.A. employees reconstructing the former street car (before that, used by railroad) tunnel for future vehicular use. Shown in the background is the automobile ramp around Grand Central station that this will hook up to.

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

Park Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street, Manhattan
Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer
[Note: negative is at Museum of the City of New York]
Code I D
Oct. 8, 1936

folder: Park Avenue - 39th Street, west side, Manhattan, NY
title: Park Avenue - 39th Street, west side

text:
East 39th Street, west from Park Avenue. At the left and right respectively are an open lot and the Princeton Club. At Madison Avenue is another clearance. View 2 is closer to same. This emphasizes the reconstructed former residence housing the administrative staff of the Henry Street Nursing Service. It stands at the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue. Mrs. Goadby Loew, the daughter of George F. Baker, resided here.

April 11, 1940
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

East 39th Street, west from Park Avenue. At the left and right respectively are an open lot and the Princeton Club. At Madison Avenue is another clearance. View 2 is closer to same. This emphasizes the reconstructed former residence housing the administrative staff of the Henry Street Nursing Service. It stands at the S.E. corner of Madison Avenue. Mrs. Goadby Loew, the daughter of George F. Baker, resided here.

April 11, 1940
No's. 1-2

P. L. Sperr

Park Avenue, south from E. 39th Street (intersection in foreground) as viewed southwestward from what the writer believes to be the Chanin Building, showing several high apartment houses and the Union League Club. The latter is the square Colonial facade structure seen in the center of bot views. The two apartment houses facing each other at 38th Street are the 70 Park Avenue and the Murray. View No. 2 is southeastward from an office building at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 39th Street and emphasizes a rear view of the last named structures and the club.
About 1932.
Views 1 and 2

MAY BE REPRODUCED.

Park Avenue, south from E. 39th Street (intersection in foreground) as viewed southwestward from what the writer believes to be the Chanin Building, showing several high apartment houses and the Union League Club. The latter is the square Colonial facade structure seen in the center of bot views. The two apartment houses facing each other at 38th Street are the 70 Park Avenue and the Murray. View No. 2 is southeastward from an office building at the northwest corner of Madison Avenue and 39th Street and emphasizes a rear view of the last named structures and the club.
About 1932.
Views 1 and 2
